Package infodynamics.measures.continuous.kraskov

Class MultiInfoCalculatorKraskov

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.MultiInfoCalculatorCommon
      • infodynamics.measures.continuous.kraskov.MultiInfoCalculatorKraskov
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous, MultiInfoCalculator, java.lang.Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    MultiInfoCalculatorKraskov1, MultiInfoCalculatorKraskov2
    public abstract class MultiInfoCalculatorKraskov
extends MultiInfoCalculatorCommon
implements java.lang.Cloneable

    Computes the differential multi-information of a given multivariate set of observations (implementing MultiInfoCalculator), using Kraskov-Stoegbauer-Grassberger (KSG) estimation (see Kraskov et al., below). This is an abstract class to gather common functionality between the two algorithms defined by Kraskov et al. Two child classes MultiInfoCalculatorKraskov1 and MultiInfoCalculatorKraskov2 then actually implement the two algorithms in the Kraskov et al. paper

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for MultiInfoCalculator, with:

    • For constructors see the child classes.
    • Further properties are defined in setProperty(String, String).
    • Computed values are in nats, not bits!

    Finally, note that Cloneable is implemented allowing clone() to produce only an automatic shallow copy, which is fine for the statistical significance calculation it is intended for (none of the array data will be changed there).

    References:

    • Kraskov, A., Stoegbauer, H., Grassberger, P., "Estimating mutual information", Physical Review E 69, (2004) 066138.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www), Ipek Ã–zdemir

      Size of dynamic correlation exclusion window.

      Private variable to record which KSG algorithm number this instance is implementing

      we compute distances to the kth nearest neighbour

      protected k-d tree data structure (for fast nearest neighbour searches) representing the joint space
      protected double noiseLevel
      Amount of random Gaussian noise to add to the incoming data
      protected int normType
      The norm type in use (see PROP_NORM_TYPE)
      protected int numThreads
      Number of parallel threads to use in the computation; defaults to use all available.
      static java.lang.String PROP_ADD_NOISE
      Property name for an amount of random Gaussian noise to be added to the data (default 1e-8 to match the noise order in MILCA toolkit.).
      static java.lang.String PROP_DYN_CORR_EXCL_TIME
      Property name for a dynamics exclusion time window otherwise known as Theiler window (see Kantz and Schreiber).
      static java.lang.String PROP_K
      Property name for the number of K nearest neighbours used in the KSG algorithm (default 4).
      static java.lang.String PROP_NORM_TYPE
      Property name for what type of norm to use between data points for each marginal variable -- Options are defined by KdTree.setNormType(String) and the default is EuclideanUtils.NORM_MAX_NORM.
      static java.lang.String PROP_NUM_THREADS
      Property name for the number of parallel threads to use in the computation (default is to use all available)
      protected UnivariateNearestNeighbourSearcher[] rangeSearchersInMarginals
      protected data structures (for fast nearest neighbour searches) representing the marginal spaces
      static java.lang.String USE_ALL_THREADS
      Valid property value for PROP_NUM_THREADS to indicate that all available processors should be used.

      • setProperty

        public void setProperty​(java.lang.String propertyName,
                        java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets properties for the KSG multi-info calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, include:

        • PROP_K -- number of k nearest neighbours to use in joint kernel space in the KSG algorithm (default is 4).
        • PROP_NORM_TYPE -- norm type to apply to working out the norms between the points in each marginal space. Options are defined by KdTree.setNormType(String) - default is EuclideanUtils.NORM_MAX_NORM.
        • PROP_DYN_CORR_EXCL_TIME -- a dynamics exclusion time window, also known as Theiler window (see Kantz and Schreiber); default is 0 which means no dynamic exclusion window.
        • PROP_ADD_NOISE -- a standard deviation for an amount of random Gaussian noise to add to each variable, to avoid having neighbourhoods with artificially large counts. (We also accept "false" to indicate "0".) The amount is added in after any normalisation, so can be considered as a number of standard deviations of the data. (Recommended by Kraskov. MILCA uses 1e-8; but adds in a random amount of noise in [0,noiseLevel) ). Default 1e-8 to match the noise order in MILCA toolkit.
        • Any property accepted by the superclass MultiInfoCalculatorCommon.setProperty(String, String)

        Unknown property values are ignored.

        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface MultiInfoCalculator
        Overrides:
        setProperty in class MultiInfoCalculatorCommon
        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception

        Computes the local values of the multi-information, for each valid observation in the previously supplied observations (with PDFs computed using all of the previously supplied observation sets).

        If the samples were supplied via a single call i.e. MultiInfoCalculator.setObservations(double[][]), then the return value is a single time-series of local channel measure values corresponding to these samples.

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as MultiInfoCalculator.addObservations(double[][]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array.

        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface MultiInfoCalculator
        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local multi-info values in nats (not bits!)
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

                                               throws java.lang.Exception

        Specified by:
        computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations in interface MultiInfoCalculator
        Parameters:
        states - series of multivariate observations (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        Returns:
        the series of local multi-information values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeFromObservations

        protected double[] computeFromObservations​(boolean returnLocals)
                                    throws java.lang.Exception
        This protected method handles the multiple threads which computes either the average or local multi-info (over parts of the total observations), computing the distances between all tuples in time.

        The method returns:

        1. for (returnLocals == false), an array of size 1, containing the average multi-info
        2. for local multi-infos (returnLocals == true), the array of local multi-info values
        Parameters:
        returnLocals - whether to return an array or local values, or else sums of these values
        Returns:
        either the average multi-info, or array of local multi-info value, in nats not bits
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • partialComputeFromObservations

        protected abstract double[] partialComputeFromObservations​(int startTimePoint,
                                                           int numTimePoints,
                                                           boolean returnLocals)
                                                    throws java.lang.Exception
        Protected method to be used internally for threaded implementations. This method implements the guts of each Kraskov algorithm, computing the number of nearest neighbours in each dimension for a sub-set of the data points. It is intended to be called by one thread to work on that specific sub-set of the data.

        The method returns:

        1. for average Multi-infos (returnLocals == false), the relevant sums of digamma(n_x+1) in each marginal for a partial set of the observations
        2. for local MIs (returnLocals == true), the array of local MI values
        Parameters:
        startTimePoint - start time for the partial set we examine
        numTimePoints - number of time points (including startTimePoint to examine)
        returnLocals - whether to return an array or local values, or else sums of these values
        Returns:
        an array of sum of digamma(n_x+1) for each marginal x, then sum of n_x for each marginal x (these latter ones are for debugging purposes).
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
